author: washingtonpost.com
title: Remembering Ken Denlinger
text:
October 9 at 7:41 PM Regarding the Oct. 4 obituary for Ken Denlinger, “ Former Post columnist, author of sports books ”:
Years ago, I played in a golf tournament and fundraising event where Denlinger was the guest speaker. I had a chance to visit with him, and I invited him to play in a member-guest outing at the Country Club of Fairfax. He accepted, and we spent the day together and, although we did not win anything, had a good time.
Denlinger shared a story from covering the Masters in Augusta, Ga., when officials allowed him and other reporters a once-in-a-lifetime chance to play the course on the Monday after the tournament.
Denlinger’s handicap was 15 at the time. He said he was playing the eighth hole when he turned to his playing partner and told him, “I still have not seen this course from inside the ropes!”
It says a lot about the man that he would relate such a self-deprecating story. He was a good person.
Owen V. Cummings , Lusby
●
Ken Denlinger was a class act and displayed integrity in his columns.
In early 1977, The Post editorialized that the Report of the President’s Commission on Olympic Sports, of which I was executive director, had recommended an imitation of East Germany’s sports system for the United States .
Five days later, Denlinger refuted his own paper’s editorial — with eloquence, facts and courage.
He will be missed.
Mike Harrigan , Darnestown
